Award.AwardTitle: Contact structures, Floer homology and TQFT
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Award: DMS-0805352
Principal Investigator: Ko Honda

Recently it has become more evident that contact structures play
a central role in low-dimensional topology and Topological
Quantum Field Theories (TQFTs). The cut-and-paste theory of
contact structures in dimension three, developed by numerous
authors including the PI, can now be imported into Heegaard Floer
homology, a (3+1)-dimensional TQFT. The PI, together with his
collaborators, seeks to better understand the relations among
contact geometry, Floer homology theories, TQFTs and string
theory, and hyperbolic geometry. More specifically, the PI
proposes the following: (1) Analyze the TQFT properties of
Heegaard/sutured Floer homology. (2) Understand a certain
category obtained via contact geometry, which satisfies many of
the properties of a triangulated category. (3) Study contact
homology invariants of exact Lagrangian cobordisms between
Legendrian links in the symplectization of a contact manifold.
(4) Calculate the contact homology of tight contact structures on
hyperbolic 3-manifolds.

The PI proposes a study of 3- and 4-dimensional spaces using a
probe called a contact structure. The 3-dimensional spaces we
study will locally be similar to the standard (Euclidean)
3-dimensional space. These objects may be very complicated
globally, but a local observer cannot tell the difference, just
as an ant cannot tell whether it is sitting on a flat plane or a
very large sphere. A contact structure is a field in
3-dimensional space, analogous to an electric field in physics.
Just as the nature of the electric field, such as the strength
and the direction at any point, gives some information about the
distribution of the electric charge, i.e., the source of the
electric field, a contact structure gives information about the
shape of the ambient 3-dimensional space. A more thorough
mathematical understanding of contact structures in dimension
three may contribute significantly towards our understanding of
the shape of the universe.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There are several invariants of knots, links, and 3-dimensional spaces that arise from mathematical physics and symplectic geometry.  A knot invariant is a quantity that is assigned to a knot such that any two knots with different values cannot be deformed into one another. Questions about knotting are ubiquitous in science: from quantum computing to molecular biology (especially knotting in DNA). A 3-dimensional space (technically called a 3-manifold) is a space which locally looks like the 3-dimensional space that we live in. It might look different from far away, just as a sphere and the surface of a donut with a hole are locally indistinguishable but can be distinguished from afar. 

Two of the most powerful and useful invariants of knots and 3-dimensional spaces are Heegaard Floer homology and Seiberg-Witten Floer cohomology. I am currently putting finishing touches on joint work with Vincent Colin and Paolo Ghiggini in which we establish the equivalence of Heegaard Floer homology and Seiberg-Witten Floer cohomology. This work consists of four papers which add up to over 300 pages in total.  (An alternate proof has been given by Cagatay Kutluhan, Yi-Jen Lee, and Cliff Taubes, using very different methods.) Since Heegaard Floer homology is combinatorial and computable, while Seiberg-Witten Floer cohomology is more geometric, we expect many practical applications to ensue.


Last Modified: 06/29/2012
Modified by: Ko Honda

Since Heegaard Floer homology is combinatorial and computable, while Seiberg-Witten Floer cohomology is more geometric, we expect many practical applications to ensue.
